qas.question: What grants all indigenous languages spoken in Mexico validity?

answers.text: General Law of Linguistic Rights of the Indigenous Peoples

qas.question: What are indigenous peoples entitled to request?

answers.text: some public services and documents in their native languages

qas.question: How many languages have been giving the status of "national languages"?
What has the Mexican government promoted in some indigenous rural communities?
How many of the indigenous peoples in Mexico speak an indigenous language?

context: The "<a0_0>General Law of Linguistic Rights of the Indigenous Peoples<a0_0/>" grants all indigenous languages spoken in Mexico, regardless of the number of speakers, the same validity as Spanish in all territories in which they are spoken, and indigenous peoples are entitled to request <a1_0>some public services and documents in their native languages<a1_0/>. Along with Spanish, the law has granted them — <a2_0>more than 60<a2_0/> languages — the status of "national languages". The law includes all indigenous languages of the Americas regardless of origin; that is, it includes the indigenous languages of ethnic groups non-native to the territory. As such the National Commission for the Development of Indigenous Peoples recognizes the language of the Kickapoo, who immigrated from the United States, and recognizes the languages of the Guatemalan indigenous refugees. The Mexican government has promoted and established <a3_0>bilingual primary and secondary education<a3_0/> in some indigenous rural communities. Nonetheless, of the indigenous peoples in Mexico, only <a4_0>about 67% of them<a4_0/> (or 5.4% of the country's population) speak an indigenous language and about a sixth do not speak Spanish (1.2% of the country's population).
